Attorney General]] | termstart2 = June 2005 | termend2 = July 2006 | 1blankname2 = {{Nowrap|Attorney General}} | 1namedata2 = [[John Ashcroft]] }} {{Conservatism US|jurists}} '''Neil McGill Gorsuch''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɡ|ɔːr|s|ʌ|tʃ}} {{respell|GOR|sutch}};{{Cite news |date=March 22, 2017 |title=How to pronounce Gorsuch |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2017/live-updates/trump-white-house/neil-gorsuch-confirmation-hearings-updates-and-analysis-on-the-supreme-court-nominee/how-to-pronounce-gorsuch/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404043146/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2017/live-updates/trump-white-house/neil-gorsuch-confirmation-hearings-updates-and-analysis-on-the-supreme-court-nominee/how-to-pronounce-gorsuch/ |archive-date=April 4, 2017 |access-date=April 3, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post}} born August 29, 1967) is an American jurist who serves as an [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States|associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States]]. He was [[Neil Gorsuch Supreme Court nomination|nominated]] by President [[Donald Trump]] on January 31, 2017, and has served since April 10, 2017. Gorsuch spent his early life in [[Denver, Colorado]]. After graduating from [[Columbia University]], where he became an established writer, Gorsuch received his legal education at [[Harvard Law School]] and earned a doctorate in jurisprudence from [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] in 2004 as a [[Marshall Scholarship|Marshall Scholar]]. His doctoral thesis concerned the morality of [[assisted suicide]] and was written under the supervision of legal philosopher [[John Finnis]]. He was a [[law clerk]] for Judge [[David B. Sentelle]], Justice [[Byron White]], and Justice [[Anthony Kennedy]]. From 1995 to 2005, Gorsuch was in private practice with the law firm of [[Kellogg, Hansen, Todd, Figel & Frederick]]. He was the principal deputy associate attorney general at the [[United States Department of Justice]] from 2005 until his appointment to the Tenth Circuit. President [[George W. Bush]] nominated Gorsuch to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit]] on May 10, 2006, to replace Judge [[David M. Ebel]], who achieved [[senior status]] that same year. Gorsuch is a proponent of [[textualism]] in [[statutory interpretation]] and [[originalism]] in interpreting the [[United States Constitution]]. Along with Justice [[Clarence Thomas]], he is an advocate of [[Natural law|natural law jurisprudence]].{{Cite news |last=Kelleher |first=J. Paul |date=March 20, 2017 |title=Neil Gorsuch's "natural law" philosophy is a long way from Justice Scalia's originalism |url=https://www.vox.com/the-big-idea/2017/3/20/14976926/gorsuch-natural-law-supreme-court-hearings |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231839/https://www.vox.com/the-big-idea/2017/3/20/14976926/gorsuch-natural-law-supreme-court-hearings |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=March 9, 2018 |work=Vox}} He is the first Supreme Court justice to serve alongside a justice for whom he once clerked (Kennedy).{{Cite news |last=Livni |first=Ephrat |date=April 7, 2017 |title=Neil Gorsuch is the first US Supreme Court justice to sit on the bench with his high-court boss |url=https://qz.com/953345/neil-gorsuch-is-the-first-us-supreme-court-justice-to-sit-on-the-bench-with-his-high-court-boss/ |access-date=August 16, 2017 |work=Quartz}} During his tenure on the Supreme Court he has written the majority opinion in [[List of landmark court decisions in the United States|landmark cases]] such as ''[[Bostock v. Clayton County]]'' on LGBT rights, ''[[McGirt v. Oklahoma]]'' on Native American law, ''[[Kennedy v. Bremerton School District]]'' on personal religious observance while serving in an official capacity, and ''[[Ramos v. Louisiana]]'' on juries' guilty verdicts. == Early life and education == Gorsuch was born on August 29, 1967, in [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]].{{Cite web |title=The Supreme Court: Justice Neil M. Gorsuch |url=https://supremecourthistory.org/supreme-court-justices/associate-justice-neil-m-gorsuch/ |access-date=March 3, 2024 |website=[[Supreme Court Historical Society]] |language=en-US}} His parents were [[Anne Gorsuch Burford]] (née McGill; 1942–2004) and David Ronald Gorsuch (1937–2001).{{Cite web |date=August 28, 2019 |title=Neil Gorsuch |url=https://www.biography.com/law-figure/neil-gorsuch |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210816160258/https://www.biography.com/law-figure/neil-gorsuch |archive-date=August 16, 2021 |access-date=October 1, 2021}}{{Cite web |date=February 1937 |title=David Ronald Gorsuch |url=https://www.geni.com/people/David-Gorsuch/6000000053652938864 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231724/https://www.geni.com/people/David-Gorsuch/6000000053652938864 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=November 27, 2017 |publisher=geni.com}} He was the eldest of three children,{{Cite web |last1=Liptak |first1=Adam |last2=Baker |first2=Peter |last3=Fandos |first3=Nicholas |last4=Turkewitz |first4=Julie |date=February 4, 2017 |title=In Fall of Gorsuch's Mother, a Painful Lesson in Politicking |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/04/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court-nominee.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210517222710/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/04/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court-nominee.html |archive-date=May 17, 2021 |access-date=May 17, 2021 |website=The New York Times}} and is a fourth-generation Coloradan.{{Cite news |last=de Vogue |first=Ariane |date=February 1, 2017 |title=Meet Neil Gorsuch: A fly-fishing Scalia fan |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/31/politics/neil-gorsuch-antonin-scalia/index.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231835/https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/31/politics/neil-gorsuch-antonin-scalia/index.html |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=February 1, 2017 |work=CNN}} John McGill, his maternal grandfather, was a surgeon, and his paternal grandfather, John Gorsuch, was an established lawyer in [[Denver, Colorado]].{{Sfn|Greenya|2018|p=9–10, 14}} Both of Gorsuch's parents were also attorneys.{{Sfn|Greenya|2018|p=11}} They encouraged their children to engage in debate, often spontaneously. From 1976 to 1980, Anne Burford served in the [[Colorado House of Representatives]] from 1976 to 1980. In 1981, she was appointed by President [[Ronald Reagan]] as the first woman to serve as [[Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency|administrator]] of the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]].{{Cite news |last=Savage |first=David G. |date=January 24, 2017 |title=Conservative Colorado judge emerges as a top contender to fill Scalia's Supreme Court seat |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-supreme-court-gorsuch-20170123-story.html |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}{{Cite news |last1=Kindy |first1=Kimberly |last2=Horwitz |first2=Sari |last3=Wan |first3=William |date=February 19, 2017 |title=Simply stated, Gorsuch is steadfast and surprising |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/simply-stated-gorsuch-is-steadfast-and-surprising/2017/02/18/4015bf18-f153-11e6-8d72-263470bf0401_story.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231852/https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/simply-stated-gorsuch-is-steadfast-and-surprising/2017/02/18/4015bf18-f153-11e6-8d72-263470bf0401_story.html |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=February 20, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}} Her conservative views contrasted with those of her husband, who was a [[Liberalism in the United States|liberal]].{{Sfn|Greenya|2018|p=14}} Gorsuch attended Christ the King Roman Catholic School, a private [[grade school]] in Denver. The school's moral lessons influenced him and he was remembered by classmates for assuming strong stances. He assisted his mother in her campaign for the Colorado legislature at age nine. After her appointment, Gorsuch's family moved to [[Bethesda, Maryland]]. He enrolled in [[Georgetown Preparatory School]],{{Cite web |title=Notable Alumni |url=https://www.gprep.org/about/alumni/notable-alumni |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231820/https://www.gprep.org/about/alumni/notable-alumni |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=February 25, 2017 |publisher=Georgetown Preparatory School}} a selective [[Jesuit]] [[college-preparatory school]], arriving as a freshman in 1981.{{Cite web |date=September 26, 2018 |title=Inside the high school that produced Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, Justice Neil Gorsuch and other famous alums |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/inside-high-school-produced-supreme-court-nominee-brett/story?id=58093123 |access-date=April 11, 2023 |website=ABC News |language=en}} He was two years junior to future justice [[Brett Kavanaugh]], a classmate he later clerked with at the Supreme Court. Gorsuch was a member of Georgetown Prep's [[Debate team|debate]], forensics, and international relations clubs,{{Cite news |last=Mervosh |first=Sarah |date=July 10, 2018 |title=Kavanaugh and Gorsuch Both Went to the Same Elite Prep School |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/10/us/kavanaugh-gorsuch-georgetown-prep.html |access-date=April 11, 2023 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}} and served as a [[Page of the United States Senate|United States Senate page]] in the early 1980s.{{cite web |title=Nomination of Neil M. Gorsuch, Nominee to be Circuit Judge for the Tenth Circuit |url=https://www.congress.gov/109/chrg/shrg32199/CHRG-109shrg32199.pdf |website=congress.gov |publisher=Government Printing Office |access-date=June 4, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240405230305/https://www.congress.gov/109/chrg/shrg32199/CHRG-109shrg32199.pdf |archive-date=April 5, 2024 |location=Washington, D.C. |page=2 |date=June 21, 2006 |url-status=live}} He graduated in 1985 as student body president; in contrast to Kavanaugh, he was described as a fairly outgoing and extroverted student.{{Cite web |date=July 9, 2018 |title=Trump's Two SCOTUS Picks Also Went to High School Together - Washingtonian |url=https://www.washingtonian.com/2018/07/09/brett-kavanaugh-neil-gorsuch-georgetown-prep/ |access-date=April 11, 2023 |language=en-US}} Gorsuch attended [[Columbia University]] after high school, graduating in 1988 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]], ''[[Latin honors#North America|cum laude]]'', in [[political science]]. He undertook a heavier courseload to graduate in three years.{{Cite web |last=Vinciguerra |first=Thomas |date=Fall 2017 |title=The Education of Neil Gorsuch |url=https://magazine.columbia.edu/article/education-neil-gorsuch |access-date=April 11, 2023 |website=Columbia Magazine |language=en}} As an undergraduate, he wrote for the ''[[Columbia Daily Spectator]]''{{Cite web |date=October 1, 1985 |title=Columbia Daily Spectator |url=http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19851001-01.1.3&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN------ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231852/http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19851001-01.1.3&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN------ |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=January 31, 2017 |publisher=spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu}} and co-founded the satirical student publication ''[[The Fed (Columbia newspaper)|The Fed]]'' in 1986.{{Cite web |last=Quigley |first=Aidan |date=February 2017 |title=At Columbia, Gorsuch blasted progressive protesters, defended free speech |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/02/neil-gorsuch-viewpoints-opinion-columbia-234498 |access-date=April 11, 2023 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Marhoefer |first=Laurie |date=December 1, 1999 |title=The History of Columbia's Oldest Student Paper |url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/thefed/v3/volume15/5/fedhistory.shtml |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231848/http://www.columbia.edu/cu/thefed/v3/volume15/5/fedhistory.shtml |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=January 28, 2017 |publisher=[[The Fed (Columbia newspaper)|The Fed]]}} Gorsuch distinguished himself as an active debater and an ardent conservative, publishing pieces that criticized left-wing politics. After a brief stint as a writer for a short-lived journal, he led efforts to establish ''The Fed'' as a conservative alternative to liberal campus newspapers. He was a member of the [[Phi Gamma Delta]] fraternity{{Sfn|Greenya|2018|p=32}} and was inducted into the [[Phi Beta Kappa]] honor society.{{Cite news |last=Clarke |first=Sara |date=January 31, 2017 |title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Neil Gorsuch |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-01-31/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-neil-gorsuch |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231856/https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-01-31/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-neil-gorsuch |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=February 2, 2017 |work=U.S. News & World Report}} After graduating from Columbia, Gorsuch attended [[Harvard Law School]] on a [[Harry S. Truman Scholarship]].{{Cite web |title=Joseph E. Stevens Award | The Harry S. Truman Scholarship Foundation |url=https://www.truman.gov/joseph-e-stevens-award/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161213223108/https://www.truman.gov/joseph-e-stevens-award/ |archive-date=December 13, 2016 |access-date=April 3, 2017 |website=Truman.gov}}{{cite web |url=http://today.law.harvard.edu/president-trump-nominates-neil-m-gorsuch-91-u-s-supreme-court |title=Neil M. Gorsuch '91 nominated to the U.S. Supreme Court |publisher=Harvard Law Today |date=January 31, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231855/https://today.law.harvard.edu/president-trump-nominates-neil-m-gorsuch-91-u-s-supreme-court/ |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |url-status=live}} He was an editor of the ''[[Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy]]''{{Cite web |title=Hon. Neil Gorsuch |url=http://www.fed-soc.org/experts/detail/neil-gorsuch |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170125080902/http://www.fed-soc.org/experts/detail/neil-gorsuch |archive-date=January 25, 2017 |publisher=The Federalist Society}} and was a member of the [[Lincoln's Inn Society]], the Harvard Prison Legal Assistance Project, and the Harvard Defenders program.{{Cite web |last=Halper |first=Jamie D. |date=February 1, 2017 |title=Harvard Law Graduate Neil M. Gorsuch Nominated to Supreme Court |url=https://www.thecrimson.com/article/2017/2/1/gorsuch-nominated/ |access-date=April 12, 2023 |website=[[The Harvard Crimson]]}} Gorsuch was described as a committed conservative who supported the [[Gulf War]] and [[Term limits in the United States|congressional term limits]] on "a campus full of ardent liberals".{{Cite news |last=Levenson |first=Michael |date=February 2, 2017 |title=At Harvard Law, Gorsuch stood out on a campus full of liberals |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/02/01/harvard-law-gorsuch-known-for-congenial-conservatism/VVWPaO55Xm2WSO6yyfAilM/story.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231858/https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/02/01/harvard-law-gorsuch-known-for-congenial-conservatism/VVWPaO55Xm2WSO6yyfAilM/story.html |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=February 25, 2017 |work=[[Boston Globe]]}} Despite his contrasting political views, he was generally well-liked by students.{{Sfn|Greenya|2018|p=38, 42}} Philip C. Berg, a classmate and close friend, remembered him as "very sensitive" and non-confrontational, recalling when he received Gorsuch's support in [[coming out|coming out as gay]].{{Cite web |last=Halper |first=Jamie D. |date=February 9, 2017 |title=Former Classmates Reflect on Gorsuch's Law School Days |url=https://www.thecrimson.com/article/2017/2/9/gorsuch-law-school/ |access-date=April 12, 2023 |website=[[The Harvard Crimson]]}} Gorsuch graduated in 1991 with a [[Juris Doctor]], ''[[Latin honors#North America|cum laude]]''. Future president [[Barack Obama]] was among his classmates.{{Cite news |last=Clauss |first=Kyle Scott |date=February 1, 2017 |title=Neil Gorsuch, Trump's Supreme Court Pick, Attended Harvard Law with Obama |url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/blog/2017/02/01/neil-gorsuch-trump-supreme-court-harvard-law |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202151116/http://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/blog/2017/02/01/neil-gorsuch-trump-supreme-court-harvard-law/ |archive-date=February 2, 2017 |access-date=February 3, 2017 |work=[[Boston (magazine)|Boston]] |location=[[Boston, Massachusetts]]}} == Early legal career == === Clerkships === Gorsuch served as a [[law clerk]] for Judge [[David B. Sentelle]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit]] from 1991 to 1992. After spending a year at [[University College, Oxford|Oxford]], later earning a doctorate as a [[Marshall Scholarship|Marshall Scholar]], Gorsuch clerked for Justices [[Byron White]] and [[Anthony Kennedy]] from 1993 to 1994.The same 1993 Term, Gorsuch's Harvard Law School classmates David T. Goldberg (HLS 1991) and [[Julius Genachowski]] (HLS 1991) both [[Law clerk of the Supreme Court of the United States|clerked]] for Justice David Souter. His work with White occurred right after White retired from the Supreme Court; therefore, Gorsuch assisted White with his work on the Tenth Circuit, where White sat by designation. Gorsuch was part of a group of five law clerks assigned that year that included [[Brett Kavanaugh]], who described Gorsuch at the time, saying: "He fit into the place very easily. He's just an easy guy to get along with. He doesn't have sharp elbows. We had a wide range of views, but we all really got along well."{{Sfn|Greenya|2018|p=55}} === Private law practice === Instead of joining an established law firm, Gorsuch decided to join the two-year-old boutique firm of Kellogg, Huber, Hansen, Todd, Evans & Figel (now [[Kellogg, Hansen, Todd, Figel & Frederick]]), where he focused on trial work. After winning his first trial as lead attorney, a jury member told Gorsuch he was like [[Perry Mason]]. He was an associate in the Washington, D.C., law firm from 1995 to 1997 and a partner from 1998 to 2005.{{Cite book |last=Congress |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W6gziQydtBwC&pg=PA289 |title=Neil M. Gorsuch |date=July 20, 2006 |isbn=978-0-16-086155-0 |series=[[Congressional Record|Congressional Record—Senate]] |volume=152 |page=15346 |access-date=June 12, 2017 |via=[[Google Books]] |issue=11}}{{Cite news |last=Mauro |first=Tony |date=January 24, 2017 |title=Three Things to Know About Neil Gorsuch, SCOTUS Front-Runner |url=http://www.nationallawjournal.com/home/id=1202777522924/Three-Things-to-Know-About-Neil-Gorsuch-SCOTUS-FrontRunner |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231744/https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/almID/1202777522924/Three-Things-to-Know-About-Neil-Gorsuch-SCOTUS-FrontRunner/?slreturn=20210114181734 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=January 27, 2017 |work=[[The National Law Journal]]}}{{subscription required}} Gorsuch's clients included Colorado billionaire [[Philip Anschutz]].{{Cite news |last1=Charlie Savage |author-link=Charlie Savage (author) |last2=Julie Turkewitz |date=March 15, 2017 |title=Neil Gorsuch Has Web of Ties to Secretive Billionaire |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231744/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court.html |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=March 20, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]] |page=A1}} At Kellogg Huber, Gorsuch focused on commercial matters, including [[Contract law|contracts]], [[Competition law|antitrust]], [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act|RICO]], and [[securities fraud]]. In 2002, Gorsuch wrote an op-ed criticizing the Senate for delaying the nominations of [[Merrick Garland]] and [[John Roberts]] to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]], writing, "the most impressive judicial nominees are grossly mistreated" by the Senate. In 2004, Gorsuch received a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in legal philosophy from the [[University of Oxford]], where he completed research on [[assisted suicide]] and [[euthanasia]] as a postgraduate student at [[University College, Oxford|University College]].{{Cite thesis |last=Gorsuch |first=Neil McGill |title=The right to receive assistance in suicide and euthanasia, with particular reference to the law of the United States |date=2004 |access-date=February 15, 2017 |degree=DPhil |publisher=[[University of Oxford]] |url=https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:688e5b8c-bb06-4d86-abe0-440a7666ffc1 |oclc=59196002 |id={{EThOS|uk.bl.ethos.401384}} |website=ora.ox.ac.uk |archive-date=March 31, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331142804/https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:688e5b8c-bb06-4d86-abe0-440a7666ffc1 |url-status=live}} {{free access}} A [[Marshall Scholarship]] enabled him to study at Oxford in 1992–93, where he was supervised by the [[natural law]] philosopher [[John Finnis]].{{Cite web |last=Warren |first=Ashley |title=Judge Neil M. Gorsuch ('92) sworn in to US Supreme Court – Association of Marshall Scholars |url=https://www.marshallscholars.org/in-the-news/judge-neil-m-gorsuch-92-sworn-in-to-us-supreme-court/ |access-date=March 2, 2019 |website=www.marshallscholars.org |publisher=Association of Marshall Scholars}} His thesis was also supervised by Canadian legal scholar [[Timothy Endicott]] of [[Balliol College, Oxford]].{{Cite web |title=Judge Neil M. Gorsuch |url=http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/judges/judge-neil-m-gorsuch |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202050829/http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/judges/judge-neil-m-gorsuch |archive-date=February 2, 2017 |access-date=February 6, 2018 |website=Administrative Office of the United States Courts |publisher=The United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit}} In 1996, Gorsuch married Louise, an Englishwoman and champion [[Equestrianism|equestrienne]] on Oxford's riding team whom he met during his stay there.{{Cite news |last=Rayner |first=Gordon |date=February 1, 2017 |title=British family of Donald Trump Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch 'thrilled but terrified' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/01/british-family-donald-trump-supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231740/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/01/british-family-donald-trump-supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch/ |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |access-date=October 7, 2018 |work=The Telegraph |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}} === U.S. Department of Justice === Gorsuch served as Principal Deputy to the [[United States Associate Attorney General|Associate Attorney General]], [[Robert McCallum Jr.|Robert McCallum]], at the [[United States Department of Justice]] from June 2005 until July 2006.{{Cite web |last=Kim |first=Seung Min |date=March 9, 2017 |title=DOJ sends 144,000 pages of Gorsuch documents to Senate |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/03/justice-department-neil-gorsuch-documents-senate-235885 |access-date=April 10, 2023 |website=POLITICO |language=en}} As McCallum's principal deputy, he assisted in managing the Department of Justice's civil litigation components, which included the antitrust, civil, [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]], environment, and tax divisions. While managing the [[United States Department of Justice Civil Division]], Gorsuch was tasked with all the "terror litigation" arising from the president's [[War on Terror]], successfully defending
